title: How to Cook Ginataang Tilapia

steps.headline: Heat 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pan with deep sides.
steps.description: Turn on the cooktop to medium-high heat and allow the pan to begin warming up. Swirl the oil in the bottom of the pan so that it coats the entire surface—this will ensure more even heating and help prevent sticking. The pan will appear to shimmer when the oil is hot enough to cook with. Choose an oil with a high smoke point that’s suitable for frying, such as peanut, vegetable, or canola oil. You’ll eventually be stewing all of the main components together, so make sure the pan you use is big enough to hold everything.

steps.headline: Add the onion, garlic, and ginger.
steps.description: Throw your aromatics into the pan together and give them a good toss or stir to mix them. Keep the pieces moving continuously to expose them to a consistent amount of heat and avoid burning them. Frying the aromatics briefly before introducing the rest of your ingredients will unlock more of their natural pungent flavor.

steps.headline: Cook the aromatics until the onions soften.
steps.description: You should notice the onions taking on a translucent appearance within 3-5 minutes. Once they begin to caramelize slightly, reduce the temperature of the cooktop to medium heat. Onions sometimes have to cook for quite a while before they lose their crunch, so it’s a good idea to get them started ahead of the tilapia.

steps.headline: Heat 1½ tablespoons of fish sauce in the pan.
steps.description: Add the fish sauce directly to the sautéed onions, garlic, and ginger and stir thoroughly. Let the mixture sit until the fish sauce just begins to bubble—this should only take 1-2 minutes. For this recipe, it will be best to use a traditional Filipino patis, or a Vietnamese style fish sauce like nuoc mam. It’s important to lower the cooking temperature before adding the fish sauce. Intense heat may cause sauces with added sugar to burn, which could affect the finished flavor of the dish.

steps.headline: Add the coconut cream.
steps.description: The cream will initially come out in one thick clump, but will begin to thin as it warms up. Stir the aromatics, fish sauce, and coconut cream together vigorously until they’re completely incorporated. As you did before, wait for the liquid components to come to a bubble before moving on. Use your spoon to scrape the remnants out of the jar or can. You don’t want to waste any of that creamy goodness! You can also use raw, unsweetened coconut milk in place of the heavier coconut cream. However, this may cause the finished dish to take on a slightly soupier consistency.

steps.headline: Sprinkle in salt and pepper to taste.
steps.description: Be sure to sample the base before salting it too heavily. The fish sauce will lend the dish most of its saltiness, so it may not need much. After you’ve gotten the seasoning just right, turn the cooktop down to low-medium heat to bring the base to a low simmer. Feel free to add any other spices or seasonings of choice at this point, such as fresh ground turmeric to impart earthy undertones or chili flakes to kick the heat up another notch. The heat should be low enough for the base to just bubble around the edges.

steps.headline: Simmer the base for 3-5 minutes.
steps.description: This will give the individual flavors a chance to mingle, resulting in a more complex and balanced dish. It will also help work out any remaining lumps in the rich coconut cream. Be sure to stir the base periodically to prevent it from congealing around the edges. Keep an eye on the pan to make sure it doesn’t get too hot. Coconut cream is prone to scorching.

steps.headline: Add the tilapia and banana peppers to the pan.
steps.description: Position the fish in the center of the cooking surface and spoon the base over the top to cover them. You may only be able to cook 2-3 fish at a time, depending on their size and the size of the pan. If you’re making dinner for a crowd, it might be necessary to fix multiple batches. Ginataang tilapia is traditionally made using the whole fish, but you can also substitute fillets that have already been cut up and deboned. The banana peppers can be sliced or left whole, depending on your preferences.

steps.headline: Simmer the tilapia and peppers for 30-35 minutes.
steps.description: Place the lid on the pan, leaving it offset by a couple inches. Then, set a timer to help you keep track of how long the fish has been cooking. By the 30 minute mark, it will have soaked up much of the complex flavor from the base. The meat inside should be nice and tender, with a soft white color and slightly flaky texture. Venting the pan will ensure that the components don’t become soggy while also retaining a little moisture to prevent the base from reducing too much. If the tilapia still looks a little underdone after the first 30 minutes, continue simmering it for around 5 minutes at a time until it’s cooked through.

steps.headline: Incorporate any other desired ingredients.
steps.description: Some cooks like to prepare ginataang tilapia with additives like red chili peppers or mustasa (a type of traditional leafy green) to make the dish more filling and give it a burst of festive color. These should be added in the last 3-5 minutes of cook time, as they don’t take long to soften. Spinach will make an acceptable substitute if you’re unable to find mustasa greens. If you’re not big on spicy food, try using sliced bell peppers, cherry tomatoes, eggplant, or other mild veggies in place of the hotter chilis.

steps.headline: Heat the ingredients together for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Once you’ve got everything in the pan, increase the temperature to a medium-high heat. Let the ingredients simmer for an additional minute or so to make sure they’re nice and hot. When time’s up, remove the pan from the cooktop, portion the tilapia, sauce, and veggies onto separate serving plates. Enjoy it while it’s hot! Transfer any leftovers to an airtight storage container and place them in the refrigerator. When properly stored, they should keep for 3-4 days.
